Name: State Bank of South Carolina
Notes:
It was used by the State Bank of South Carolina in 1852. Struck by Union cannon balls during the Civil War.

Built in the Renaissance Revival style using Connecticut brownstone. It was fully renovated three times, having survived bombardment, hurricanes, and a major earthquake. Renovated in 2015 by the owners of the coffee shop currently housed on the first floor.

Name: DeNillo Art Gallery
Notes: Best known for her work in cut canvas art, Laura has been featured on The Travel Channel and in some of the finer hotels in the country, including The Grand Bohemian in Orlando, The Casa Monica and the Concord. For over 30 years Laura has created paintings for homes and restaurants all over the country and Europe. Currently, her work hangs in her own gallery in Charleston.

Name: Printer's Row
Notes: Used by Walker, Evans, and Cogswell engravers and stationers. Offices existed behind this building on 3 Broad Street. They are best known for the printing of Confederate "graybacks." Since converted to condominium units.

Name: John Blake Building
Notes:
Former paint shop and only house on Rainbow Row without a color. George Flagg's paint shop was here in pre-Revolutionary times, which stocked pigment and oils for the painting of Charleston's houses. It burned in the fire of 1778, after which Flagg sold the lot to John Blake in 1791.

The kitchen building for this house at 1 Elliot Street has been converted into a residence.

Name: Dutarque, Guida
Notes:
Built by Lewis Dutarque. Once a merchants' office, a notary's office, a paint store and then a grocery store. This house is the only in Rainbow Row to retain its Victorian storefront, with large windows to attract the attention of passers-by.

Building was later owned by the Italian immigrant grocer Giovanni Domenico Guida, whose name is embossed in the pediment. He added the pressed metal storefront and lintels.

Name: Joseph Dulles
Notes:
Built by Scottish merchant Joseph Dulles as his counting house. Joseph was an ancestor of Allen Dulles, who in turn was the first director of the Central Intelligence Agency. He, along with his brother John Foster Dulles, who was secretary of state at the time and namesake of Dulles airport of Washington DC, promoted a strong nationalist agenda for the United States.

Allen Dulles oversaw the 1961 Bay of Pigs Invasion and was on the Warren Commission to investigate the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

In the 1930s, art historian Miss Anna Wells Rutledge added the curious, off-center gable, and installed a door and a garage door to replace the storefront.

Name: Othniel Beale
Notes:
Built by wharf owner Othniel Beale from the harbor town of Marblehead, MA. Some of the few houses on Rainbow Row to survive the fire of 1778, and the first to be restored by preservationists in the 1930s.

Col. Othniel Beale rebuilt the city's harbor fortifications and became a member of the Governor's Council. He built the house to serve as his family home across from his wharf.

The second-floor wrought-iron balcony came from the demolished C.F. Prigge House at 7 Elizabeth Street. The initials "CP" can be seen on the railing.

The back of the house provided the romantic site which inspired the first stage set for "Porgy and Bess."

Name: Othniel Beale
Notes:
Note the Neoclassical revival fanlighted doorway. A 19th century storefront was removed and replaced with windows.

In addition to owning a wharf here, Othniel Beale owned and sometimes sailed his own ships. During a voyage aboard one of his ships, he was set upon by pirates and ordered to sail his ship to the Barbary Coast. Othniel was able to delude his captors into thinking that was exactly the intended destination. In fact, he was making all sail for the Thames! He succeeded in getting the ship into port before the pirates guessed his design, and was received and rewarded by the King.

He then returned to Carolina, where he spent the rest of his life, made a fortune, became a member of the Commons and afterward President of the Council. In his spare time, he engineered Charleston’s colonial fortifications.

Name: Othniel Beale
Notes:
Othniel's houses, #95-#101, were the only ones to survive the fire of 1778 on Rainbow Row. Note the curvilinear gable and rope molding. Storefront was replaced by two windows.

Once owned by Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, delegate to the Constitutional Convention.

Name: James Cook
Notes: Remodeled in 1836 with a Greek Revival façade. The original house burned in the 1778 fire. James Cook replaced it with a house, shop and Flemish gable. A 1941 restoration added the single dormer.

Name: George Inglis
Notes: Constructed ca. 1778, leased by George Inglis, replaced ca. 1782 by tea importers Leger & Greenwood. Their tea was confiscated by Charleston citizens during the Charleston Tea Party of 1773. Original building leased by Scotsman George Inglis. It had an arch leading to an alley. Restored as a house in 1938, maintaining Greek Revival features and adding a "bulls-eye" in the roof pediment.

Name: Deas, Tunno
Notes:
Home of Adam Tunno, the "King of the Scotch," who bought the property in 1787. Adam Tunno was one of Charleston's richest merchants. The original house was destroyed by the fire of 1778. The current house was built by David Deas during or just after the American Revolution.

The property included outbuildings such as slave quarters and warehouses stretching to Bedon’s Alley, which is between Elliott and Tradd streets.

Name: James Gordon
Notes: Largest house on Rainbow Row, built by Scottish merchant and planter James Gordon, and the only house on Rainbow Row to retain its original stucco finish.

Name: Smith, deSaussure, Darrell
Notes:
A small-gauged railway ran through the present entry door to storerooms in the back, which was originally a covered passage.

English merchant James Osmond owned the original house before it was destroyed in the fire of 1778. Luder Sahlmann used the building as a storage warehouse for his feed-and-grain business next door.

Name: William Stone
Notes:
Numerous merchants used the ground floor as counting houses.

The house was also used as a grain and feed store, always maintaining a residence on the three stories above.

Ravaged by the fires of 1740 and 1778, this 4½-story house was built by William Stone, a Tory merchant who constructed the post-1740 building and retired to England during the Revolution.

The doorway is in the Colonial Revival style. The rear courtyard was converted from a demolished brick warehouse of which only the walls remained.

The term "counting house" is used in the nursery rhyme Sing a Song of Sixpence: "The king was in his counting house, counting out his money...."

Name: Lindsay Bulwinkle
Notes:
Built by Robet Lindsay and operated in 1845 by Henry Bulwinkle. The first two floors of 79 East Bay Street were part of a corner, two-story grocery store. The prominent crossed earthquake bolts are a response to the near total collapse of 2,000 buildings in the Southeastern United States after the earthquake of 1886.

The Gaud School used the building from 1940 to 1953 after which it was converted for residential use.

Name: Thomas Barksdale
Notes:
Built by Thomas Barksdale, nephew of George Barksdale of the Barksdale House Inn on George Street. Also known as 1 Tradd Street.

A simple single house built of brick and covered with stucco.

The second floor iron balcony was added during a restoration in 1927. During the time of Charleston's preservation fervor, the structure was restored by Mrs. T.W. Punnett, a cousin of Franklin D. Roosevelt. (Buildings of Charleston.)

Name: 75 E Bay
Notes:
No historical information is available.

3 bedrooms, 3 baths, 3,094 sqft. Estimated value $2M.

Name: Ugly Duckling
Notes: There was a 3-story house dating from some time before 1835 that was the “ugly duckling.” Tradition claims that it burned and was replaced by the current house.

Name: 71 E Bay
Notes:
A commercial building before 1900, converted into a residence for Mrs. Nicholas Roosevelt, ca. 1930, by architect Albert Simons.

Mrs. Nicholas Roosevelt was married to the diplomat Nicholas Roosevelt

3 bedrooms, 4 baths, 3,700 sqft. Estimated value $2.1M.

Name: 69 E Bay
Notes:
No historical information is available.

4 bedrooms, 4.5 baths, 3,030 sqft. Estimated value $2.2M.

Name: 63 E Bay
Notes:
Federal style house renovated in 2005.

3 bedrooms, 4 baths, 3,078 sqft. Estimated value $3.1M.

Name: 59 E Bay
Notes:
The land was granted to Thomas Rose in 1678, and later was the site of the Commercial Cotton Press and Wharf Company. Current home is a two-story brick structure with an unusual central chimney.

4 bedrooms, 4.5 baths, 3,298 sqft. Estimated value is $2.8M.

Name: Thomas Pinckney
Notes:
Thomas Pinckney bought the original house in 1692.

The first house burned in the fire of 1778; the current house traces back to 1783.

The house became the home and grocery store of William Porter in 1826.

Name: Jonathan Simpson
Notes:
Features include Tuscan columns, pediment, and a semicircular fanlight that appear to derive from the pattern book of the English builder William Pain.

This house bears the distinction of being one of the final houses of prostitution in this part of Charleston, last raided by the police in 1958.

Name: Charleston Club
Notes:
Note the dentilled brick cornice and wrought-iron balcony with a crossed star center panel. Originally for men only, the first woman was invited to the club in 1938.

Starting in 1852, The Charleston Club was located at 45 Meeting Street, 3 Meeting Street, 22 South Battery, 45 East Bay Street, 78 East Bay Street and finally here in 1958. Currently it shares its space with three apartments.

Name: Caspar Christian Schutt
Notes:
Caspar Christian Schutt was one of Charleston’s few wealthy German merchants. One of the largest Charleston Single houses ever built in the city. The triple-tiered piazzas boast graduating orders of Doric, Ionic and Corinthian columns.

It is rare in that a full complement of outbuildings, including the original kitchen, carriage house, servants' quarters, and stables, still stand.

The house was saved from a planned condominium project and remains a single family residence.

Three bedrooms, 10k sqft. Estimated value is $9M.

Name: Anne Boone
Notes:
Anne Boone was the daughter of landgrave Daniel Axtell.

Her father, sadly, was hanged, drawn, and quartered for participating in the assassination of King Charles I, who was also father of Charleston's namesake. Anne was one of the refugees welcomed to Carolina by the Lords Proprietors. The north wall of the house, with its original stucco and arched staircase windows, survives almost wholly intact.

Name: Somersall DeSaussure
Notes:
Built by merchant William Somersall. The house now has 19th century Greek Revival and Italianate detailing added by Confederate General Wilmot G. de Saussure.

Divided into 2 bedroom condos, 1800 sqft. Estimated value $1.5M.

Name: George Sommers
Notes:
Formerly this building, like many Charleston single houses, maintained an entrance on the street facade and a front ground-floor room for commercial purposes. In the early 19th century the door was closed and the piazzas added, as was the late Federal style piazza door screen. The bend in East Bay just beyond this lot led the area to be known in the 1700s as Sommers Corner. This very bend impelled the builder of the Sommers House to follow the diagonal of the street in the construction of the front facade.

This house is very close to the location of the city wall.

Name: Whaley Huiet
Notes:
Attorney W. Gibbes Whaley, who served for many years as master in equity, completed this stuccoed wood dwelling by 1902. The 2-story, hipped-roof building with mixed Beaux Arts and Neoclassical detailing, was sold within 2 years of its completion to William and Louisa Fait. William Fait had moved to Charleston only a few years earlier to manage the Charleston Canning Company but sold this house in 1906. The Huiet and Paul families owned 41 East Bay Street for most of the 20th century. The bowed porch with a ground-story masonry arcade and upper balustrade was apparently added after 1940.

This house is very close to the location of the city wall.

Name: Missroon House & Granville Bastion
Description: Constructed in 1789. Headquarters of the Historic Charleston Foundation. Bastion remains exist in the basement.
Notes: Remains of the Granville Bastion, the fortification that protected the southeast corner of the original 1680 settlement of Charles Towne, are preserved in the basement. Capt. James Missroon, of Londonderry, Ireland, was involved in maritime trade and owned this home in 1808.

Name: George Chisolm
Notes:
Due to its location, this house allows harbor views from every window.

The Federal style wooden dwelling in an L-shape presents a two-story, five-bay front facade with a pediment and lunette window projecting from the hip roof. A street doorway formerly accessed the northeast room from East Bay Street. The double-tiered side piazzas follow the shape of the building and provide access to the principal entry architrave with its elliptical fanlight.

Name: Nathaniel Ingraham
Notes:
Built by Nathaniel Ingraham, a merchant who served on John Paul Jones' Bonhomme Richard, a merchant ship on loan from France, converted to a warship. After it was shell damaged by the bombardment in 1864, its post-war owner, Anna Wells, and her husband, Confederate hero and writer Dr. Edward Wells, made various changes, including installation of a Second Empire mansard roof, cast-metal cornice, and window heads.

Water Street is the south border of the walled city.

Name: Henry Porter Williams
Notes: Renovated 1903. Due to its location, this house allows harbor views from every window. When Henry Porter Williams was given the choice between this home and his father's, the Calhoun Mansion on Meeting Street, he chose this dwelling. Williams remodeled the house in 1903, raised the structure 3 feet above ground level, and stuccoed the exterior. Also during the renovation, part of the rear piazza was enclosed and the kitchen dependency was connected to the main house.

Name: Porcher Simonds
Notes:
Built by cotton broker Francis Porcher. After 1894, John C. Simonds, son of the builder of the Villa Margherita at 4 South Battery, renovated the house in a mix of Beaux Arts Classicism and Renaissance Revival detailing, adding paired columns on the square portico and a double-tiered, semicircular front piazza.

In 1983, the house was converted into three condominiums.

Name: Charles Drayton
Notes: Built by Charles Drayton, of the family of Drayton Hall Plantation. The house's Eastlake detailing is unusual. A collection of antebellum dependencies is in the rear.

Name: Edmondston Alston
Notes: Built by Scottish shipping merchant Charles Edmondston. He was forced to sell the house after the panic of 1837. It was bought by Charles Alston, a member of a well-established Low Country rice-planting dynasty. He soon added the Greek Revival improvements to the house.

Name: Julius Visanska
Notes: Designed by by Charleston's leading restoration architect, Albert Simons. The house reflects a curious mix of features, including yellow brick which was costly at the time, corner brick quoining, Renaissance style loggia entry, and tripartite windows in the Greek Revival manner. The residence was taken over by the Navy in 1942, which used it for the duration of World War II. (Poston, Buildings of Charleston.)

Name: Mevers
Notes:
Built in the Colonial Revival style. Divided into two apartments. First apartment is 1 bedroom, 1 bath, and 1,050 sqft. Estimated rent is $2,650/month.

Second apartment is 2 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, and 1,900 sqft. Estimated rent is $6000/month.

Name: William Ravenel
Notes: Built by William Ravenel, owner of one of Charleston's major steamship lines and brother of John Ravenel of 5 East Battery. Held by the Ravenels until the 1930s, only two other families have lived in this house.

Name: Robert William Roper
Notes:
Built by the cotton planter and state legislator. At the time this house was built, the view of the harbor was unobstructed. This Greek Revival house, with its prominent position on the southern edge of the Battery, has a massive 5-columned Ionic portico that could be seen by approaching ships miles away.

Original plans were for White Point Park to reach up to this house. The financial panic of 1837 encouraged the city to sell the lots in front, predicting that they "will produce a beautiful row of ornamental buildings along the whole line of East Bay Battery."

Name: John Ravenel
Notes:
Built by John Ravenel, merchant and ship owner, who soon passed it on to his son, Dr. St. Julien Ravenel. The house was designed in the Italianate style, as characterized by the flat roof with the cornice border. Dr. St. Julien Ravenel, the planter, designed the Confederate semi-submersible craft Little David, was also a pioneer of Charleston's postwar phosphate industry, and was considered the father of Charleston's artesian well system.

St. Julien's mother was Anna Eliza Ford, was likely related to Elizabeth Ford, who was married to Henry William de Saussure of 18 Montagu Street. Elizabeth was baptized 25 October 1767 at First Presbyterian Church, Morristown, NJ, which is the town where St. Julien got his education after grammar school. She also belonged to the family that owned Ford Mansion, which was Washington's headquarters during the Revolutionary War.

Currently owned by Frances Palmer, a multi year long restoration has been underway to convert what was a bed and breakfast to a private residence.

Name: Louis de Saussure
Notes:
Built by French Huguenot and wealthy businessman Louis de Saussure, just in time for bombardment from Union ships during the Civil War. This house has survived bombardment and earthquakes to remain on its perch of perhaps the most desirable location in all of Charleston. It was purchased by the Irish wholesale grocer Bernard O'Neill, officer of the Hibernian Society, representative in the State Legislature, and grandfather of Elizabeth O'Neill Verner, one of Charleston's most loved artists. She was active during the Charleston Renaissance from 1915 to 1940.

The house is now three condominiums, one, 1 bedroom and two 2 bedrooms. Estimated values $1.3M to $1.7M.

Name: James Chapman
Notes:
Chapman was a commission merchant in stocks and real estate, and then resident owner of the dwelling across the street at 6 Water Street, who added another small parcel and created two building lots here by 1857. The identical houses constructed by Chapman follow the Italianate, with central pavilions flanked by an entry bay on the east side and a screen for a masked piazza on the west. Stucco quoins on the first-floor corners become pilasters with bracketed capitals on the second story. The front gable with its dentilled cornice frames a Venetian window, and the roof behind boasts three dormers.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, and 4,101 sqft. Estimated value is $2.8M.

Name: James Chapman Tenements
Notes:
Chapman was a commission merchant in stocks and real estate, and then resident owner of the dwelling across the street at 6 Water Street, who added another small parcel and created two building lots here by 1857. The identical houses constructed by Chapman follow the Italianate, with central pavilions flanked by an entry bay on the east side and a screen for a masked piazza on the west. Stucco quoins on the first-floor corners become pilasters with bracketed capitals on the second story. The front gable with its dentilled cornice frames a Venetian window, and the roof behind boasts three dormers.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, and 4,101 sqft. Estimated value is $2.8M.

Name: Francis Saltus
Notes: Evidence suggests that the builder was Francis Saltus, who purchased the land from the Rivers family in 1818. The property was sold to Otis Mills in 1832. He likely held this property for investment and rental income. During the later decades of the 19th century, the house was converted to a tenement and by the early part of the 20th century, carved into 10 apartments. Conversion back to a single family residence occurred in the 1960s. Fortunately, the basic single house plan remained intact with enough of the original elements to identify this as a Federal style residence.

Name: 8 Water St
Notes:
Three-story wood single house altered with bowed front piazzas in the Eastlake style during in the 19th century. Front door is decorated by a transom bar and side light.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, and 2,801 sqft. Estimated value is $1.8M.

Name: Swain-Hussey
Notes:
The lot was acquired by mariner Luke Swain and stretched to Stoll's Alley on the north and to Church Street on the west. The house faced the alley currently behind the house and had piazzas overlooking Vanderhorst Creek, which soon thereafter became Water Street. Swain sold the property to another mariner, George Hussey, in 1800.

Of particular note, two doors with twin Neoclassical architraves provide separate entries to the front rooms, a characteristic of some Cooper River Plantation houses but unknown in the city.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 4 baths, and 2,742 sqft.Estimated value is $1.9M.

Name: Joseph Righton
Notes:
Joseph Righton, a successful cooper, constructed several houses in the neighborhood, building this dwelling for his son. Originally built to face White Point and the Ashley river beyond.

This house has 4 beds 7 baths 5,500 sqft.Estimated value is $3.6M.

Name: 46 Church
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 3 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, and 1,600 sqft. Estimated value is $1.4M.

Name: McCully Righton
Notes:
Wealthy cooper McCully Righton purchased a portion of Grand Modell lot 298 on the south side of the canal that was filled to become Water Street. This is a traditional Charleston single house consisting of a 2½ story main block on a high masonry foundation sheltered on the west by a double-tiered piazza screened by an Italianate style entry door.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 4 baths, and 4,150 sqft. Estimated value is $2.8M.

Name: 48 Church
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 4 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, and 2,721 sqft. Estimated value is $1.6M.

Name: E.J.H. Fischer
Notes:
Queen Anne style house, like its single house neighbors at 46 and 48 Church Street. Built by E.J.H. Fischer by 1889. The church incurred heavy damage in the earthquake of 1886 the property was sold to Fischer. The 2-story wood house has detailing such as heavy bracketed cornice and balustrade bay window more often found on houses in the area west of Legare Street.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, and 3,582 sqft. Estimated value is $2.2M.

Name: Charleston Port Society
Notes:
By 1828, the Charleston Port Society for the Promotion of the Gospel Among Seaman maintained a home at 52 Church Street.

This house has 3 beds 1 bath 2,299 sqft. Estimated value is $1.5M.

Name: 54 Church
Notes: No historical information is available. 4 bedrooms, 3 baths, 4,371 sqft. Estimated value $2.5M.

Name: James Veree
Notes: James Veree, a French Huguenot carpenter, purchased a parcel containing the lots where 56, 58, and 60 Church Street stand in 1754. The house retains its early piazza containing a notable door architrave with engaged and fluted Doric columns supporting a Classical Revival frieze.

Name: James Veree
Notes:
Former home of Mrs. Emily Whaley and is the setting for her 1997 book, Mrs. Whaley and Her Charleston Garden. This house was also owned by Thomas Heyward, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The land parcels for #56, #58 and #60 were bought in 1754 by James Veree.

The house boasts a celebrated rear garden, attracting visitors from around the world. Though Mrs. Whaley passed away in 1998, the house has remained in the family her daughter, noted Charleston artist Marty Whaley Adams, who continues to maintain the garden.

Name: Veree-Duvall
Notes: The outstanding feature of this 2-story frame dwelling is the west 1st-floor room, having pre-Revolutionary mahogany paneling with fretwork inlay, possibly attributable to Martin Pfeninger, a German cabinetmaker living in Charleston in the 1770s. After Veree moved to Burlington, New Jersey, he sold 60 Church to Stephen Duvall, a bar pilot, who furnished it elaborately, according to his surviving estate inventory. An officer in the South Carolina navy in the Revolution, Duvall died of a fever while imprisoned by the British under the Exchange Building in 1780. (Poston, Buildings of Charleston.)

Name: Mary W. Fife
Notes: Beneath is a well and "a drain," maybe used for sulfur baths, providing hot springs to the LowCountry. The owner, John Woddrop, conveyed the lot to widow Mary W. Fife, who probably built the current house. Fife's son sold the property to druggist James Heilbrun, owner of several other sites along Church Street. Heilbrun operated "sulfur baths" in the mid-19th century.

Name: 64 Church St
Notes: No historical information is available. 4 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, 2,565 sqft. Estimated value $2M.

Name: John McCall
Notes: Built by city treasurer John McCall. Note how the first floor masonry wall - added in the 20th century for apartments - diminishes the effect of the multi-tiered piazzas. The house was later owned by Thomas Rose Sr. (Father of the builder of 59 Church Street.)

Name: 68 Church
Notes: No historical information is available. 4 bedrooms, 4 baths, 4,484 sqft. Estimated value $3.4M.

Name: 70 Church
Notes: No historical information is available. 6 bedrooms, 4 baths, 3.2K sqft. Estimated value $2M.

Name: 72 Church
Notes: No historical information is available. This house has 3 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, 1,868 sqft. Estimated rent is $5,400/month.

Name: Russell-Dehon Tenement
Notes: This house is a replacement for one that burned in 1778. Sarah Russell-Dehon was a member of the Nathaniel Russell family, whose more famous house is at 51 Meeting Street. 2 bedrooms, 3 baths 1,750 sqft. Estimated value $2M.

Name: DuBose Heyward
Notes:
Home of DuBose Heyward, writer of "Porgy", the novel that was the basis of George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess." The opera was first performed in Boston in 1935, but not in Charleston until 1970 because of "white opposition." Despite pleadings from DuBose Heyward before his death in 1940, the city would not permit a performance of "Porgy and Bess." The 1959 movie Porgy and Bess starring Sidney Poitier and Dorothy Dandridge was also banned.

Earlier history of this house tells that President George Washington spoke from the balcony of #78 during his visit to Charleston in 1791.

Name: 80 Church
Notes: No historical information is available. This house has 2 bedrooms, 2.5 baths 2,600 sqft. Estimated value $2.2M.

Name: William Mills
Notes: Built by Scottish Presbyterian merchant William Mills, who gave it to his son Thomas in 1799. Thomas had a brother, Robert. It's possible that the Washington Monument designer spent some of his youth in this house. This building was originally a Charleston Single house with a shop on the ground floor, a covered, wrought-iron balcony, and a hipped roof.

Name: 84 Church
Notes: In 1982 a request was made to allow a museum here, although it would have bit quite small. 1 bedroom, 1.5 bath, 966 sqft. Estimated value is $885K.

Name: Isaac Mazyck
Notes: Isaac Mazyck III built the house following the fire of 1778. The fire of 1778 began at the "bake-house of one Moore at the north end of Union Street." It was detected at 4:00AM and extinguished at noon, but in that time 250 houses were destroyed. Revolutionary war soldiers and mariners in Charleston were essential in stopping the conflagration.

Name: Thomas Legare
Notes: Built by Huguenot Peter Leger, containing a two story slave quarters and kitchen. The middle window was once a door, indicating a shop operated here. House was owned by Thomas Legare.

Name: Alexander Christie
Notes:
Alexander Christie, a Scottish merchant, built this three-and-a-half story Adamesque house. It had a storefront door that was replaced by a window and visibly newer bricks. The house has been the rectory of St. Phillip's Church since 1908.

Lots close to the wharves had the affect of pushing up real estate values, making properties on streets like Meeting and King more affordable during the 1800s.

Name: Cooper-Bee
Notes: Built by the merchant John Cooper and his wife Mary. Thomas Bee was the subsequent owner, a delegate to the Continental Congress and nominated by George Washington to become a United States judge. Thomas Bee was the owner from 1771 to 1799.

Name: Ann Peacock
Notes:
Built by William Hall for Ann Peacock, a wealthy widow from St. George's Parish, Dorchester, SC.

Photo courtesy of Spencer Means.

Name: Bank of the United States
Notes:
The initial location of the first Bank of the United States, chartered in 1790, that failed in 1930 during the Great Depression, losing nearly $180 million in deposits.

Today it is the home of Magnolia Bride, where you can also lose money, but at least for a good reason.

The arched entrance was the bank entrance, while the residential was on the opposite end of the front façade.

During the antebellum period, the house was owned by Mary A.S. Marion, a member of a prominent Berkeley County plantation family, that included General Francis Marion, the famed "swamp fox."

Name: Peabody Watercolors
Notes: No historical information is available. Gallery for Peabody Watercolors at 102 Church Street and rental condo at 38 Elliott Street. Condo has 2 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, 2,043 sqft. Estimated rent is $4,500/month.

Name: #104 Church
Notes:
Operated as business and residence for over 100 years. House has 7 bedrooms, 3 baths, 4,000 sqft. Estimated value $1.7M.

Today it is the Charleston office of Detterbeck Wealth Management.

Name: #106 Church
Notes:
goat. sheep. cow. is a gourmet wine, cheese and charcuterie market.

Helena Fox Fine Art is a gallery of fine American representational art.

Name: #110 Church
Notes: Possibly one of the earliest surviving structures in the old Walled City.

Name: Cannon-Kirkland
Description: Constructed ca. 1796-1810. Built by lumberjack Daniel Cannon. Dr. Kirkland was a later owner and doctor who experimented with "electricity."
Notes: The most distinctive feature of the building is the wall with high balustrade separating the first story of the piazza from the carriage driveway.

Name: Gay Sanders Fisher Gallery
Description: Constructed ca. 1790. Gallery of the renowned watercolorist and former church organist.

Name: Charles Mouzon
Notes: Built by Charles Mouzon With its gable end to Church Street and 3 bays on each floor surmounted by a tripartite window at the top ½ story. The building stretches along Chalmers Street. Also referred to as 20 Chalmers Street.

Name: John Carroll Doyle Art Gallery
Description: Constructed ca. 1801. Currently the art gallery of late American impressionist John Carroll Doyle.

Name: #121
Description: Constructed in 1790. 2 bedrooms, 2 baths, 2,400 sqft. Estimated value $1.6M.
Notes: Owners included Josiah Taylor and Thomas O'Brian.

Name: #115
Description: Constructed in 1946. The building replaced a stable.
Notes: Note the Art Moderne style, featuring a flat roof, rounded corners and minimal ornamentation.

Name: #111-113
Description: Constructed in 1978. Two office rentals, 800 and 1500 sqft.
Notes: No historical information is available.

Name: Isaac Holmes Tenement
Notes: Isaac Holmes built this brick and stuccoed three-and-a-half story house after the fire of 1740. There were other people of the same name, so he referred to himself as "Isaac Holmes of Church Street."

Name: 105 Church
Notes: No historical information is available. The house has 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, 1,634 sqft. Estimated value is $1.4M.

Name: George Hoffman
Notes: Land was owned by Joel Poinsett, an ambassador to Mexico and prominent Charleston lawyer. Joel Poinsett was the one after whom the poinsettia plant was named. Note the Flemish bond brick on the façade of the house (wide and narrow sides of the bricks alternate.) The house was sold to George Hoffman in 1816.

Name: 99 Church
Notes:
Charleston Improvement Corp houses built 93-101 on what was formerly a cotton press. Houses feature Queen Anne style, unusual for Church Street. This was the former location of the Charleston Hydraulic Cotton Press Company and was replaced by four Victorian homes. The Queen Anne style gable ends, and front piazzas, varied somewhat from the double-tiered porches of #97.

#101 was a restaurant that burned at an unknown time, and was replaced with the current parking lot.

Name: 97 Church
Notes:
Charleston Improvement Corp houses built 93-101 on what was formerly a cotton press. Houses feature Queen Anne style, unusual for Church Street. This was the former location of the Charleston Hydraulic Cotton Press Company and was replaced by four Victorian homes. The Queen Anne style gable ends, and front piazzas, varied somewhat from the double-tiered porches of #97.

#101 was a restaurant that burned at an unknown time, and was replaced with the current parking lot.

Name: 95 Church
Notes:
Charleston Improvement Corp houses built 93-101 on what was formerly a cotton press. Houses feature Queen Anne style, unusual for Church Street. This was the former location of the Charleston Hydraulic Cotton Press Company and was replaced by four Victorian homes. The Queen Anne style gable ends, and front piazzas, varied somewhat from the double-tiered porches of #97.

#101 was a restaurant that burned at an unknown time, and was replaced with the current parking lot.

Name: 93 Church
Notes:
Charleston Improvement Corp houses built 93-101 on what was formerly a cotton press. Houses feature Queen Anne style, unusual for Church Street. This was the former location of the Charleston Hydraulic Cotton Press Company and was replaced by four Victorian homes. The Queen Anne style gable ends, and front piazzas, varied somewhat from the double-tiered porches of #97.

#101 was a restaurant that burned at an unknown time, and was replaced with the current parking lot.

Name: 89-91 - Catfish Row
Notes: So named by DuBose Heyward and borrowed by George Gershwin became the first American Opera. The double, three story tenement was actually called "Cabbage Row" because black tenants sold cabbages on the window sills. Note the wrought iron grill in the central, arched passage.

Name: Heyward-Washington
Notes:
Built by Daniel Heyward and home of his son Thomas Heyward, a signer of the Declaration of Independence.The house hosted George Washington in 1791 and became Charleston's first house museum in 1929. Thomas Heyward hosted George Washington during his visit in 1791.

When the bank note for the house came due in the 1940s with no means of payment, the newly formed Historic Charleston Foundation raised the funds to save the house, thanks to money raised during its spring house tours. The tour of this house continues to draw visitors from around the world, today.

Name: W. Hendricks Tenement
Notes:
Tenement features a shared chimney which was employed as an effective tax evasion technique. Christ Church planter William Hendricks built this tenament as a speculative venture. The former double kitchen with a massive shared chimney could be seen through the arch.

The tenement was also considered a dependency, which is a building attached to a main house, such as a stable or separate kitchen.

Name: Anthony Bonneau
Notes: Huegenot immigrant Anthony Bonneau was the original owner of the lot in 1694. The lot was later purchased by John Bullock, who left it to his widow, Mary Bullock. She bequeathed it to their daughter, Milicent, who married Col. Robert Brewton (#71). He sold the house to John Frazier in 1722.

Name: Louis Danjou
Notes:
Grocer Louis Danjou, from Cluny, France, had his shop on the ground floor and lived above it.

Also called "Brewton's Corner" after the grand jury foreman who lived in a former house, here, who indicted pirate Stede Bonnet in 1718.

Name: Thomas Dale
Notes: Col. Miles Brewton "for love and affection" gave this house to his daughter, Mary, and son-in-law, Dr. Thomas Dale as a gift. Note the presence of an early central chimney (shared by the front of the house with the back, on the left), a construction feature replaced by party wall chimneys in late-18th and 19th century Charleston Single houses.

Name: Robert Brewton
Notes:
Col. Robert Brewton was a successful wharf owner and militia officer with rank of Powder Receiver. One of the oldest examples of the Charleston Single. Features a wrought iron balcony, formal garden and piazzas in the rear, added later. Early Single houses did not have piazzas. Corner blocks are known as quoins.

With the rank of Powder Receiver, Col. Brewton was entrusted with the collection of taxes levied on gunpowder delivered on merchant ships.

Name: Jacob Motte
Notes:
Built by Richard Capers and leased by city treasurer and Battle of Sullivan's Island veteran Jacob Motte and his wife, Rebecca Brewton Motte, a patriot who supplied food and provisions to the Continental Army for five years. As designated by the Charleston Assembly, Jacob Motte kept government funds in his personal possession. He was also the only banker in town, obtained great wealth through legal commissions, fathered 19 children and was father-in-law of Gen. William Moultrie.

The house was heavily damaged by Federal bombardment, but was purchased and fully restored by Mrs. William Mason Smith after the war. Her descendent, renowned artist Alice R. Huger Smith, lived here.

Name: First Baptist Church
Notes:
Oldest Baptist church in the South which was originally a wooden church constructed in 1699. Its congregation, from Kittery, Maine, moved south because of persecution. British commander Lord Cornwallis feared it's minister more than the Continental armies. The church was designed by South Carolina architect Robert Mills, who also designed the Washington Monument.

The minister from Maine was persecuted for his "rash and inconsiderate words tending to blasphemy" by the mother church in Boston before relocating his congregation here in 1699.

A later minister of this church had a zeal that was well-known. When Charleston was seized by the British during the Revolution. Lord Cornwallis, the British commander stated that he "feared the prayers of the young Baptist minister more than the armies of Marion and Sumter." That minister was Richard Furman, founder of Furman University in South Carolina near Greenville.

Name: Thomas Rose
Notes:
Believed to be haunted by the ghost of Dr. Joseph Brown Ladd. Built by planter Thomas Rose.

The whistling ghost of Dr. Joseph Brown Ladd is said to inhabit this house, having been mortally wounded after a duel to defend the honor of an actress named Mary Darby Robinson, whose nickname was "Perdita" (heroine of Shakespeare's "The Winter's Tale"). She was the first public mistress of King George IV.

Name: Benjamin Phillips
Notes: Known for its spectacular rear formal garden. The Late-Neoclassical style shows a departure from the Charleston Single, with its side door entering a hallway allowing access to rooms.

Name: Joseph Ball
Notes:
A fine example of the classic Charleston Single House. The Ball family owned 20 rice plantations that were worked by nearly 4,000 slaves. To accommodate comfortable sleeping arrangements, porches were placed where they received the greatest exposure to prevailing breezes, making it possible to sleep during the sweltering summer months.

The Ball family owned the house for nearly 100 years.

Note the closed gable end and Tuscan-columned piazzas. The building has served for many years as the parsonage for the First Baptist Church.

Name: Joseph Verree
Notes:
Joseph Verree, who built this fine Georgian house, was a prosperous master carpenter of colonial Charles Town and an active Patriot and member of the Sons of Liberty during the American Revolution. He was married to Mary Ball, daughter of Joseph Ball.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 5 baths, and 3,505 sqft. Estimated value is $2.9M.

Name: 45 Church
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 4 bedrooms, 4 baths, and 4,420 sqft. Estimated value is $2.4M.

Name: Joseph Righton
Notes:
One of the most loved houses in Charleston, though it was probably the kitchen building of 5 Water Street, also built by Righton. The entrance was originally on Church Street. When the house was bought in 1918 by the Chisolms, they moved the entrance to Water Street and changed the chimney locations.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 5 baths, and 3,182 sqft. Estimated value is $1.2M.

Name: 42 Church
Notes: Hidden in the bend of Church Street, this late 19th-century house as a subtle Victorian flavor. The large panned windows, door hood, and turned piazza columns combine to evoke a post-Civil War design. A total renovation enhances the basic structure of the house with its high ceilings, gracious room proportions, and wonderful light.

Name: Dr. Vincent Le Seigneur
Notes:
Dr. Vincent Le Seigneur, native of Normandy and refugee from Santo Domingo, purchased this lot in 1814 and completed this masonry single house circa 1819. He is noted for operating a hospital for slaves known as the House of Health.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 8 baths, and 5,891 sqft. Estimated value is $5.8M. The distinctive crenelated tower on the north elevation was added in 1902.

Name: James McBeth
Notes:
This tall wooden single house is elevated on a high brick foundation, which protects the principal rooms from rising tides and catches sea breezes. The garage, a luxury in Charleston, is tucked underneath the drawing room.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 5 baths, and 3,610 sqft. Estimated value is $2.4M.

Name: Lindsay-Fowler
Notes:
Built by Robert Lindsey, a joiner and lessee of the property. The simple 2-bay, 2½ story dwelling retains its beaded weatherboarding and closed front gable.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 4.5 baths, and 3,252 sqft. Estimated value is $2.9M.

Name: 30 Church
Notes: No historic information is available. 4 beds 2.5 baths 2,850 sqft. Estimated value is $1.7M.

Name: 14 Atlantic
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 1,879 sqft. Estimated value is $1.6M.

Name: William Hinckley
Notes:
Mome of the McGillivray and Snowden families for about 150 years.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 4.5 baths, and 4,112 sqft. Estimated value is $2.9M.

Name: Thomas Young
Notes:
Thomas Young built this 2½ story, 2-bay, stuccoed single house. It has received numerous modern additions so that its molded brick cornice, 9-over-9 windows, and scored stucco are among the few original parts of this house.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 2,985 sqft. Estimated value is $2.4M.

Name: 6 Atlantic
Notes: This house has 3 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, and 2,919 sqft. Estimated value is $1.6M.

Name: John Phillips
Notes:
Features six-over-six windows which are almost all original. The street entrance features classical design with a pediment and columns.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 4 baths, and 2,588 sqft. Estimated value is $2.4M.

Name: 0 Zig Zag
Notes:
Two-story house, more than half of which was the dependency to a Water Street dwelling dating from the 1830s or 1840s.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 2,408 sqft. Estimated value is $1.3M.

Name: 3 Zig Zag
Notes: No historic information is available. The house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 2,630 sqft. Estimated value is $1.8M.

Name: 2 Zig Zag
Notes:
Frame 2½ story single house constructed late 19th century on property that originally contained 2 Atlantic Street and 2½ Atlantic Street, which was conveyed to Henry G. Street in 1875 from his brothers Thaddeus and Timothy Street.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 4 baths, and 2,914 sqft. Estimated value is $2.3M.

Name: 4 Zig Zag
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 2,478 sqft. Estimated value is $1.8M.

Name: 2 Atlantic
Notes:
2-story Queen Anne style home, which has a double-tiered front piazza that wraps around the building to the east and terminates with an octagonal tower topped by a conical roof, survives from a pair of identical dwellings built circa 1890 after the earthquake destroyed a large house on the site. Two unmarried sisters of the Waring family bought the house in 1923. Leila Waring painted miniatures of Charlestonians in the first quarter of the 20 century, carrying on an art form generally associated with the pre-photography era. She added a northeast room as her studio shortly after moving into the building. May Waring, her sister, was a well-known local writer.

This house has been broken into a 4 bedroom and a 3 bedroom condo, both valued at about $2M.

Name: Smith-Chapman
Notes:
Capt. Benjamin Smith, a shipbuilder, built this dwelling, identical to 3 Atlantic Street. Unlike the typical single house placement, this structure lies directly on the street and has no piazza. A Neoclassical style doorway accents the building, which is fronted by a modern staircase. Elizabeth O'Neill Verner, founder of the Charleston Etchers' Club and a leading exponent of the fledgling historic preservation movement, maintained a studio and residence at here.

This house has 4 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, and 3,281 sqft. Estimated value is $2.2M.

Name: Benjamin Smith
Notes:
Capt. Benjamin Smith, a shipbuilder, built this dwelling, identical to 1 Atlantic Street. Unlike the typical single house placement, this structure lies directly on the street and has no piazza. A Neoclassical style doorway accents the building, which is fronted by a modern staircase. Elizabeth O'Neill Verner, founder of the Charleston Etchers' Club and a leading exponent of the fledgling historic preservation movement, maintained a studio and residence at here.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 4 baths, and 2,668 sqft. Estimated value is $2.3M.

Name: 5 Atlantic
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 2,852 sqft. Estimated value is $2.5M.

Name: 7 Atlantic
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 5 bedrooms, 5 baths, and 4,349 sqft. Estimated value is $2.8M.

Name: Jackson-Watt
Notes:
James Watt, a grocer, completed the shell of a 2-story house.

Its early natural stuccoed surface shows evidence of original scoring, early lime wash, and paint colors.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 3,819 sqft. Estimated value is $4M.

Name: Murdock-Cheeseborough
Notes:
This 3½-story stuccoed brick house is built in the Federal style and features a hip roof, gable dormers, large chimneys, and a Tuscan columned, gabled and paneled arched entrance with tranceried sunburst transom.

Built by Archibald Murdock, the house passed through George Chisolm and Mary Motte to John Cheeseborough, who acquired it in 1852. His family retained it well into the 20th century.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 5.5 baths, and 6,478 sqft. Estimated value is $4.5M.

Name: Daniel Brown
Notes:
A mariner, Daniel Brown, completed this 3-story stuccoed house as his residence by 1796. Its stucco belt coursing and fenestration nearly match the adjoining dwelling at 24 Church Street completed by George Chisholm, a factor operating on Vanderhorst's Wharf, by 1800.

This house has 3 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, and 5,605 sqft. Estimated value is $2.7M.

Name: William Holmes
Notes:
This typical 3½-story Charleston single house, ornamented with stucco quoining and elaborate belt courses as well as a projecting pediment on the south side, still has an early-Neoclassical piazza door screen with a rectangular fanlight.

This house has 5 beds 5.5 baths 7,249 sqft. Estimated value is $4.6M.

Name: 18 Church
Notes:
Charleston single house, 3½ stories with piazzas running the length of the building.

Once the home of Thomas Gadsden, lawyer and grandson of Revolutionary War hero Christopher Gadsden.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 7 baths, and 6,875 sqft. Estimated value is $6M.

Name: 16 Church
Notes: No other historic information is available. This house has 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, and 3,445 sqft. Estimated value is $2.4M.

Name: Joseph Johnson
Notes:
Dr. Joseph Johnson, mayor of Charleston and president of the Medical Society of South Carolina, lived here. Even after numerous renovations, the house retains its original beaded cypress weatherboarding, several pairs of paneled shutters, and an early-19th century fan-lighted piazza door screen.

This house has 5 bedrooms, 6 baths, and 5,294 sqft. Estimated value is $4.5M.

Name: 8 Church
Notes: No historic information is available. The house has 4 bedrooms, unknown number of baths, and 3,178 sqft. Estimated value is $2.2M.

Name: 6 Church
Notes: No historic information is available. This house has 4 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, and 3,876 sqft. Estimated value is $3M.

Name: Villa Margherita
Notes:
The architect was Frederick P. Dinkelberg, principal designer of the Flatiron Building in New York City. First National Bank President Andrew Simonds built this house for his wife, Daisy in the Beaux-Arts style with a grand Corinthian-columned portico, attenuated cornice, second story cast-iron balcony, and impressive door architrave with engaged Ionic columns, fanlight transom, and elaborate bracketed keystone.

A hotel from 1905 to 1953, the Villa Margherita, hosted Henry Ford, Alexander Graham Bell, William Howard Taft, Grover Cleveland, Theodore Roosevelt, and Sinclair Lewis. It later returned to single family use. Estimated value is $6M.

Name: 2 South Battery
Notes: Louis de Saussure's carriage house, originally belonging to 1 East Battery. Estimated value is $2.7M.

Name: William Moultrie Monument
Description: Constructed in 2000, after failed earlier attempts.
Notes: General William Moultrie was in the Continental Army during the American Revolution. He is famous for his victory at the Battle of Fort Sullivan in 1776.

Name: Daniel Hart
Description: Constructed in 1794. Owned by Daniel Hart, a Sephardic merchant. 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, 2,728 sqft. Estimated value $1.5M.

Name: #1
Description: Constructed in 1850. Unit B in this building is a 1 bedroom, 1 bath, 626 sqft. apartment. Unit C is a 2 bedrooms, 2 baths, 1,150 sqft. apartment and Unit D is 1 bedroom, 1 bath, 588 sqft. Unit A is a retail space.
Notes: No historic information is available for this address.

Name: The Pink House
Description: Constructed ca. 1712. One of the oldest houses in Charleston, made of pink Bermuda stone.
Notes:
It's likely that the pastel colors of Charleston were inspired by the natural color of Bermuda stone, which was the primary building material in the early days of the city. Bermuda stone is porous and absorbs heat better than concrete.

The house was a tavern from 1750 to 1780. Artist Alice Ravenel Huger Smith, one of the leading lights of the Charleston Renaissance, had her studio here between 1914 and 1940.

Name: 10 Chalmers
Description: Constructed in 1942. 4 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, 2,380 sqft. Estimated value $1.5M.
Notes: No historical information exists for this house.

Name: 13 State
Description: Constructed in 1800. 3 bedrooms, 4 baths, 2,300 sqft. Estimated value $1.3M. Contains a wine cellar converted from a cistern. Featured in the book This is Charleston.
Notes: No historical information is available.

Name: Brown Dog Deli
Notes: No historical information is available, but incredible sandwiches are!

Name: Second Bank of the United States
Description: Constructed in 1817. The gilded oak eagle is original.
Notes: The building was acquired by the Bank of Charleston in 1834. The interior contains many impressive Italianate and Rococo features.

Name: Smith Building
Description: Constructed ca. 1801-15. Built by architect Hugh Smith. Note the broken pediments over the windows and the shell motifs.
Notes: Used as a series of stores, among which was the People's Bank before it built its "skyscraper (See #18)."

Name: Conner Building
Description: Constructed ca. 1850s. Law office of former Charleston mayor Joe Riley's father.
Notes: The red brick Queen Anne facade was applied in 1890 by attorney Henry W. Conner to an earlier building. In the 20th century, it contained offices for Joseph P. Riley Realty, father of Charleston's longest-serving mayor, Joseph P. Riley Jr.

Name: Walker, Evans & Cogswell
Notes:
This was the main stationer, engraving, and bookbinding store for Walker, Evans and Cogwell Co., printers of Confederate money which were also called dollars, and had the nickname "Greyback" to distinguish it from the then-new US "Greenback". From 1861 to 1865, the business relocated to a safer location in Columbia, SC to serve as a Confederate government printer. The store returned to this address and continued operations until 1982.

One of the current tenants is Elyon Massage and Boutique Spa.

Name: Longitude Lane
Description: Developed before 1788. One of the original small alleys of the city. Accessed rear buildings for houses on Tradd Street.

Name: South Carolina National Bank
Description: Original construction ca. 1778. The original building was used for a horse-drawn carriage company; book store; liquor store; newspaper offices, cigar store and restaurant.
Notes: In 1963, the three story building burned and was replaced with the current structure which housed South Carolina National Bank. The company merged with Wachovia Bank, which eventually merged with Wells Fargo Bank.

Name: Justinus Stoll
Description: Constructed ca. 1745. Home of blacksmith Justinus Stoll. 3 bedrooms, 2.5 baths, 2500 sqft. Estimated value $1.8M.
Notes: Features large garage and walled garden.

Name: #4
Description: Constructed in 1890. 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, 2,373 sqft. Estimated value $1.5M.
Notes: Two walls from an existing brick building that survived the 1886 Earthquake were used to build this house.

Name: 3 Stoll's Alley
Notes: No historical information is available. 3 bedrooms, 3.5 baths, 2,796 sqft. Estimated value $2.5M.

Name: Stoll's Alley
Description: Named after the 18th century blacksmith Justinus Stoll, one of the narrowest alleys in Charleston-just five feet wide at its the narrowest point. The alley then widens to form a gathering place.
Notes: Thoroughfares like Unity Alley, Longitude Lane, and Stoll’s Alley were not part of the original street plan, but emerged from footpath. These were later paved in brick, slate and cobblestone.

Name: Eleanor Cook Tenement
Description: Constructed c. 1820. 2 bedrooms, 4 baths, 2,618 sqft. Estimated at $1.7M.
Notes: Shortly before her death in 1821, Eleanor Cook built this masonry three-story building. A coffeehouse operated on the first floor.

Name: German Fire Steam Engine Co.
Notes: The fire of 1838 prompted construction of this fire house, which was replaced in 1888 by a new one on Meeting and Wentworth Streets. #8 became a meeting hall for the Carolina Light Infantry, and later, for black fraternal lodges. In 1981, the building became a law office.

Name: Martin Building
Notes: Built by brokers William M. Martin and John C. Martin. The front of the building is brownstone in the Italianate style.

Name: Shingler Brothers Building
Notes:
Note the inscription "Exchange Office" on the façade.

The Italian Romanesque Revival facade is made of brownstone provided by a New York stonecutter. The Shingler Brothers dealt in cotton exchanges.

Today you can "Love where you live" by visiting Lois Lane Properties.

Name: S.G. Courtenay Bookstore
Notes: Note the brownstone relief of a globe, a scroll, and books, on the the curvilinear parapet. Samuel Courtenay ran his bookstore until it became a restaurant frequented by Broad Street lawyers, though today it used by law firms as offices.

Name: Conner Building
Notes:
Law office of former Charleston mayor Joe Riley's father.

The red brick Queen Anne facade was applied in 1890 by attorney Henry W. Conner to an earlier building. In the 20th century, it contained offices for Joseph P. Riley Realty, father of Charleston's longest-serving mayor, Joseph P. Riley Jr.

The current tenant is Cabbage Row Shoppe, here to satisfy your needlepoint cravings.

Name: South Carolina National Bank
Notes:
The original building was used for a horse-drawn carriage company; book store; liquor store; newspaper offices, cigar store and restaurant.

In 1963, the three story building burned and was replaced with the current structure which housed South Carolina National Bank. The company merged with Wachovia Bank, which eventually merged with Wells Fargo Bank.

Name: Smith Building
Notes: Built by architect Hugh Smith. Note the broken pediments over the windows and the shell motifs. Used as a series of stores, among which was the People's Bank before it built its "skyscraper (See #18)."

Name: South Carolina Loan and Trust
Notes:
Built by Claudian Northrop, lawyer, Confederate soldier and Catholic priest. After the Civil War, the South Carolina Loan and Trust remodeled the building as its headquarters with the addition of fashionable, cast-iron, Italianate detailing to the new facade. Remodeled in 1870, an arched loggia with Corinthian columns, arched windows and a curvilinear gable were added.

Today you can get an excellent Filet mignon at Oak Steakhouse.

Name: The People's Building
Notes:
People's Bank intended for this to be Charleston's first "skyscraper." The building was ultimately converted into luxury condos with street level retail.

Original construction of the building was so damaging to a nearby historic residence that People's Bank had to buy it.

The tall building was viewed by the developer as a sign of "progress" while others feared it would ruin Charleston's skyline. President Taft viewed the city from the top of this building and said "I don't believe that it did ruin the skyline, but if it did, the view from up here makes it worth it."

When the building was opened in 1911, people visited just to ride the elevators.

People's Bank closed in 1936 and the building was bought by Southeastern Securities Co. The two white marble leopards at the entrance were carved from Italian marble.

Name: Jacobson Building
Notes:
The site of several banks between 1817 and 1861, this structure became the office of the newly merged newspapers The News and Courier and served as their offices until 1902.

The lower portion of the Greek Revival facade of this building still survives. The engaged pedimented portico with laurel wreath frieze and the side pilasters are of granite, while the rest of the building is a severe stuccoed brick.

Today it is the site of Normandy Farm Bakery.

Name: David Alexander
Notes:
Merchant David Alexander built this 3-story brick building. The present Victorian facade is presumed to date after the earthquake of 1886, and includes a conical-roofed turret.

Today, it is the home of Archer Construction.

Name: Edgar Wells
Notes:
Built by tailor Edgar Wells. Retains many elements of its pre-Civil War facade, especially the fenestration of its upper two stories.

Home to the Qualey Law Firm.

Name: 24 Broad
Notes: Presently the offices of Schmutz & Schmutz law firm.

Name: 25-27 Broad
Notes:
Former home of W.W. Smith Cigars and Tobacco before it was destroyed by the earthquake of 1886.

Current location of Kit Thrash Properties and Utopia ladies fashions.

Name: James Gregorie House
Notes:
Originally had a countinghouse and store on the first floor, family quarters above, and anterior dependencies for both domestic and commercial use.

The building retains the original arched brick windows on the 2nd story, indicating the former location of the family's drawing rooms. Except for the fine upper brick facade, the property now bears little resemblance to its 1797 appearance.

Currently the building is the location of The Establishment seafood restaurant.

Name: 26 Broad
Notes: No historic information is available.

Name: 29 Broad
Notes:
Built by George Macaulay and John Maynard Davis, merchants. Victorian changes include a bracketed cornice and slate mansard roof with surmounting balustrade.

Now the location of the boutique realtor Robertson Howland Properties.

Name: 30 Broad
Notes: Offices of Diamond Payment Solutions and Disher, Hamrick & Myers realtors.

Name: William Lee
Notes:
Built by the watchmaker William Lee, when he leased the building to Basil Pourie, merchant. Victorian changes include a bracketed cornice and slate mansard roof with surmounting balustrade.

Home of the Edward Dare Gallery.

Name: John Smith House and Office
Notes:
John Smith's house and office remains Broad Street's best example of an early-19th century wood storefront. Fluted pilasters between the windows supporting an entablature and similar details flanking the principal door architrave punctuate the first floor. An early wrought-iron balcony with interlocking guilloche patterns ornaments the second floor.

Daniel Ravenel Realty uses the first floor.

Name: First Federal Savings and Loan Association
Notes:
Marble-faced building with its recessed portico was constructed in 1962 for First Federal Savings and Loan Association.

It is now occupied by a branch of the South State Bank.

Name: Gilbert and John Davidson
Notes:
Built by Gilbert and John Davidson, merchants. Retains its original residential upper floors with surmounting Palladian windowed dormer projecting from the hip roof.

Downtown office for Coldwell Banker.

Name: George Macaulay
Notes:
Built by the merchant George Macaulay. The cantilevered cornice and window cornices were applied ca. 1870.

Currently the first floor is used by Read & Read realtors.

Name: #38 Broad
Notes:
The State Bank of South Carolina was chartered at this location in 1801 and is presumed to have erected this building for its use.

It is now the historical pub Blind Tiger, named after the Charleston speakeasies during the late 1800s that were called "Blind Tigers."

Name: Exchange Bank and Trust Company Building
Notes:
Features of heavily rusticated sandstone and granite marks the stylistic evolution from the Romanesque Revival architecture, pioneered by H.H. Richardson, to the characteristics of the skyscraper style emerging in large cities.

Presently, this address holds the Charleston corporate offices of the Healthcare Trust of America.

Name: 40 Broad
Description: Constructed in 1891. No historical information is available.
Notes: Now home to Brown Dog Deli.

Name: 41 Broad
Notes: No historical information. Former office of William Means Realty.

Name: 42 Broad
Notes: No historical information is available. Currently the office of Jack P Brickman, attorney.

Name: The Hatman Building
Notes:
Home of Lashes and Lace bridal salon and Old Whaling Co. soaps, candles and body products.

However, most noticeable is The Charleston Hat Man cartoon trademark on the side of the building. Though originally built as a saddle and harness shop, the building and shop were transformed by Charles Plenge, a German Taylor and haberdasher, with a pressed tin cornice and Italianate façade treatments in stucco. The Hatter mural on the west façade was likely painted by a subsequent owner in the 1890s and quickly became the trademark.

Look carefully at the cartoon and you will notice that the Hatman's body is made of hats!

Name: Citizens & Southern Bank Building
Notes: Fluted Ionic columns support the monumental portico. One of few examples of Neoclassical Revival architecture in Charleston. Prior structures were a series of taverns, one of which provided the setting for Charleston (and the Colonies') first full theatrical season in 1735. Today it is a branch of SouthState Bank.

Name: Benjamin Smith House
Notes: Built by the wealthy trader, banker, and assembly speaker Benjamin Smith. Benjamin Smith was prominent in his time, owning a 2,000 acre plantation and funding a "negro school" operated by priest Alexander Garden.

Name: Bank of South Carolina
Notes:
This is a T-shaped building; the bottom of the "T" faces Broad St. Note the marble lintels over the windows and voussoir over the door.

Window lintels (tops), voussoir (arch), and belt are made of white marble. The bank sold the building to the Charleston Library Society in 1836. The Society moved to King Street in 1914 and sold the building to the Charleston Chamber of Commerce.

Name: Clark Mills Studio
Notes:
Constructed by the merchant Benjamin Smith. The present facade, added in 1899, obscures the original roof with its oversized gable accented by stylized Renaissance Revival details including pressed metal garlands and a dentiled cornice. Once the studio of sculptor Clark Mills, who created the famous statue of Andrew Jackson in Lafayette Park in Washington, D.C., in the 20th century, it housed the law office of Mayor Thomas P. Stoney, who is remembered for establishing America's first historic district and zoning ordinance and for serving as an ardent ally of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.

Today it is the home of Sweetgrass Gallery and The Brandon Agency for marketing services.

Name: Geiger House
Notes:
Likely built for the German immigrant Geiger Family in 1771. Used as a drugstore and for retail sales. Its surviving circa 1800 woodwork is of great importance. It stands as one of the few Federal period shop interiors left in the Southeast.

Today it is home of The George Gallery.

Name: #55 Broad
Notes: Currently the home of Spencer Art Gallery.

Name: #57 Broad
Description:
No historic information is available.

Home of Merrill Benfield interior design on the left and Seyahan jewelry on the right.

Name: National Freedman's Savings Bank
Notes:
Built by the attorney John Geddes. From 1869 to 1874, 58 Broad was used by the National Freedman's Savings Bank, a national bank for African Americans. The Charleston branch, one of thirty in the nation, had 5,500 depositors and approximately $350,000 in deposits in 1873.

The Ella Walton Richardson fine art gallery can be found here today.

Name: #59 Broad
Notes: Former office of The Sherman Agency for Real Estate, Investments and Loans.

Name: Robert Downie Building
Notes:
Robert Downie, a prosperous tinsmith and metalworker, built 61 Broad Street as a shop/residence in about 1815. Most of its 4-story facade has been altered.

The office of the Steinberg Law Firm is the present-day tenant.

Name: Confederate Home
Notes:
In 1867, sisters Mary Amarinthia Snowden and Isabella Yates Snowden established the Home for the widows and orphans of Confederate Soldiers, and later a college.

#64 is an office of Wm Means Co. Insurance. #60 was the Cecil Byrne Gallery of fine art.

Name: Thomas Fleming House
Notes:
A late 19th century parapet masks the early 18th century roofline of a 2-story house built by the planter Thomas Fleming after his acquisition of the lot in 1725. The present metal facade details date from and early 20th century renovation.

Presently it holds the offices of Rosen Litigation Technology Consulting and Rosen and Associates consulting engineers.

Name: John Hume House
Notes:
Merchant John Hume built this three-story brick building with a side-passage, which originally housed a shop on the first floor and a residence above. A now-demolished outbuilding served as a winter studio for the American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse, co-inventor of Morse Code, in 1820. Coincidentally, he was born in Charlestown, MA.

Today it is leased as office space. The tenants include Charleston Facial Plastic Surgery.

Name: Josiah Smith Tenement
Notes:
Josiah Smith, a wealthy merchant, built this house for two of his sons. This double tenement was constructed in the Neoclassical style then in vogue in Charleston.

The arched entrance formerly opened as a passageway extending through the building to rear outbuildings, which have since been removed. Restored as a private dining club in the 1970s, damaged by a fire, and then restored as a restaurant, the building became the entry to an addition to the Federal Courthouse Annex.

The building is currently leased to The General Services Administration as part of the
Federal Judicial Complex.

Name: Charleston County Courthouse
Notes:
Built as capital of the colony of South Carolina. 1712 was the year when the Carolina colony was split into North and South. While still unfinished, George Washington visited this building in 1791 for architectural ideas to use when designing the White House which was yet to be built.

The courthouse has endured 2½ centuries of wars, fires, neglect, and numerous renovations and additions. The most recent renovation was in 2003 when it was restored to its 1792 Neoclassical appearance.

The Declaration of Independence was read from this building in 1776. The third floor was at various times used by The Charleston Library Society, Charleston Museum, and the South Carolina Medical Society.

Name: Federal Courthouse and Post Office
Notes:
Formerly a guard house, treasury building, armory, home of The Charleston Club and then the present building after the earthquake of 1886.

Built in the Renaissance Revival style of Winnsboro, SC, granite and the southwest corner of the "Four Corners of Law." Some of the hallmarks of the Renaissance Revival style found on the building include a prominent cornice, balustrades, and quoins (corner blocks).

Name: Charleston City Hall
Notes:
This Adamesque building is the second oldest city hall in the United States.

Formerly the location of the Beef Market in 1739. Its location near the western entrance of the walled city made it an ideal location for receiving livestock and produce from the upcountry, since herds did not need to be driven through town.

Name: St. Michael's Episcopal Church
Notes:
The oldest surviving church in the city. The church steeple was painted black during the Civil War, reducing its value as a target and resulting in no damage from cannon fire.

The bell of St. Michael's crossed the Atlantic seven times: first when imported from England in 1754, second when stolen by the British in 1782, third when returned, fourth when, after being melted by fire in Columbia in 1865 and sent back to England for recasting, fifth when returned again, and one more round trip after Hurricane Hugo in 1993.

Name: Washington Square
Description: Dedicated in 1881 at the centennial of the Yorktown surrender.
Notes:
The park contains monuments to Confederate Gen. P. G. T. Beauregard, poet laureate Henry Timrod, and a memorial dedicated to the Washington Light Infantry.

The park is known for spring azaleas, hanging spanish moss and ancient live oak trees.

Name: Daniel Ravenel House
Notes:
Typical Charleston single house, continuously occupied by descendants of the Ravenel/Mazyck families, is the oldest continuing legacy property in the city. Isaac Mazyck, a leading Charleston landowner and Huguenot immigrant, devised the lot to his daughter Charlotte in 1749.

Daniel Ravenel and his wife, of Wantoot Plantation (currently submerged at the bottom of Lake Moultrie), built the present house. The line of black-tiled outbuildings including kitchen, washhouse, stable, and slave quarters is visible from Washington Square (part of the original lot was condemned for the public square before 1820). The distinctive brick wall with arched, inset stucco panels follows a style traditional to Charleston.

This house has 8 bedrooms, 6.5 baths, and 7,469 sqft.Estimated value is $3.8M.

Name: Schachte Building
Notes:
This modified Beaux Arts building is used as residences, as a location for bible studies of St. Michael's Church and a home for Saints Alive Book & Gift Store.

"Once the site of the William Burrows house, 71 Broad Street was purchased by free person of color Jehu Jones (1769 – 1833) who operated the most exclusive hotel in the city here from 1816 until his death.

Born a slave, Jones purchased his freedom from Christopher Rogers, a tailor, in 1798. Subsequently, Jones established his own tailor business and was so successful that in 1802, he was able to broaden his business efforts by investing in real estate in Charleston and on Sullivan’s Island. By 1816, Jones and his wife Abigail were devoting their full energies to operating a hotel at 71 Broad St.

The Burrows house was dismantled in the late 1920s and a replacement structure was erected in 1930."

This quote is from the College of Charleston's special collections.

Name: #11
Description: Constructed ca. 1790-1800. This house, and the Slave Mart at 6 Chalmers Street, were owned by slave trader Ziba B. Oakes.

Name: Old Slave Mart Museum
Description: Constructed ca. 1859. Originally called "Ryan's Mart," this was a Slave auction site in 1856.
Notes:
In 1856, selling slaves north of the Custom House was prohibited, since it caused the "blocking up or obstruction of East Bay Street." As a result, many "marts" were opened on Chalmers, State and Queen streets. This is the only remaining "mart" in roughly its original form.

In 1859, auction master Z.B. Oakes purchased the property and received permission from the city to build a "shed," which he gave an impressive facade: octagonal pillars to match the German Fire Station next door and the word "MART" over a large arch with an iron gate.

About 1878, the building was converted into a two-story tenement. In 1938, it was purchased by Miriam B. Wilson, who turned the building into a museum of African and African-American Arts and History.

Today, the Old Slave Mart Museum is owned by the City of Charleston. The museum has an attendance of about 64,000 visitors per year.

Name: #18
Description: Constructed ca. 1900. Two  condos: One has 2 bedrooms, 1.5 baths, 1.4K sqft. Estimated value $980K. The other has 4 bedrooms, 3 baths, 2.7K sqft. Estimated value $1.8M.
Notes: No historical information is available.

Name: South Carolina Loan and Trust
Description: Constructed ca. 1848 by Claudian Northrop, lawyer, Confederate soldier and Catholic priest. After the Civil War, the South Carolina Loan and Trust remodeled the building as its headquarters with the addition of fashionable, cast-iron, Italianate detailing to the new facade.
Notes: Remodeled in 1870, an arched loggia with Corinthian columns, arched windows and a curvilinear gable were added.

Name: 9 Chalmers
Description: Currently the law offices of Krawcheck & Davidson.
Notes: No historical information is available.

Name: The People's Building
Description: Constructed from 1910-11. People's Bank intended for this to be Charleston's first "skyscraper." Today it contains high-end condos.
Notes:
Construction was so damaging to a nearby historic residence that People's Bank had to buy it.

The tall building was viewed by the developer as a sign of "progress" while others feared it would ruin Charleston's skyline. President Taft viewed the city from the top of this building and said "I don't believe that it did ruin the skyline, but if it did, the view from up here makes it worth it."

When the building was opened in 1911, people visited just to ride the elevators.

People's Bank closed in 1936 and the building was bought by Southeastern Securities Co. The two white marble leopards at the entrance were carved from Italian marble. The building is now a mix of office, retail and residential space.

Name: Shingler Brothers Building
Description: Constructed in 1856. Note the inscription "Exchange Office" on the façade.
Notes: The Italian Romanesque Revival facade is made of brownstone provided by a New York stonecutter. The Shingler Brothers dealt in cotton exchanges.

Name: Union Insurance Company
Description: Constructed from 1811-19. Classic Revival building with the Union Insurance company's seal at the top.
Notes: If one was insured by Union Insurance, one would also have a copy of this seal on one's house. At this time, insurance companies owned the fire companies, and were responsible for fighting fires for their insureds. However, fire fighters still put out fires, even if the house was not insured by the company.
